summary: This is an email chain between U.S. Attorney's Office personnel discussing a request from Judge Engelmayer in the FOIA case Times v. BOP. The case involves the New York Times seeking Bureau of Prisons records related to Jeffrey Epstein, with BOP withholding documents citing interference with ongoing criminal cases, including the prosecution of BOP employees on duty the night of Epstein's death.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: Recipient and sender in email chain discussing Judge Engelmayer's request regarding the FOIA case Times v. BOP, which seeks Epstein-related BOP records.

persons.name: Judge Engelmayer
persons.context: Presiding judge in Times v. BOP FOIA case who requested the U.S. Attorney to review whether documents should continue to be withheld under FOIA Exemption 7(A).

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Subject of the FOIA request; his death in BOP custody is central to the related criminal case U.S. v. Noel.

connections.description: Judge Engelmayer made a formal request to U.S. Attorney Audrey Strauss to review the FOIA withholding justification in Times v. BOP.

events.title: Oral argument in Times v. BOP
events.description: Judge Engelmayer held oral arguments in the FOIA case where he requested the U.S. Attorney review the justification for withholding BOP documents related to Epstein.

events.title: Prosecution of BOP employees (U.S. v. Noel)
events.description: Criminal case against two BOP employees on duty the night of Jeffrey Epstein's death in custody.

events.title: Prosecution of former police officer (U.S. v. Tartoglione)
events.description: Death penalty prosecution of a former police officer who murdered four people and was briefly Epstein's cellmate, including at the time of an apparent suicide attempt by Epstein.

keyFacts: The New York Times filed a FOIA lawsuit (Times v. BOP, 20-cv-833) seeking Bureau of Prisons records related to Jeffrey Epstein.

BOP withheld documents under FOIA Exemption 7(A), claiming release could interfere with two ongoing criminal cases: U.S. v. Noel (prosecution of BOP employees on duty when Epstein died) and U.S. v. Tartoglione (death penalty case of Epstein's former cellmate).
Judge Engelmayer requested U.S. Attorney Audrey Strauss to review whether the FOIA withholding justification remained valid, questioning if it was 'the sort of problem' that should persist.
The email indicates the prosecution teams for the Noel and Tartoglione cases were consulted in preparing the declaration supporting the FOIA withholdings.
The document reveals ongoing legal proceedings and FOIA battles over Epstein-related records years after his death.
